Their typical Moving On ceremony was not possible, however they were able to celebrate them "parade-style" in the car loop! Creekside staff members lined the sidewalks with banners, streamers and noise makers!

Students remained in their cars with parents and received their 5th grade t-shirt from the PTA, a certificate and treat from teachers. There was also an opportunity for parents to take photos after they had distanced from the group.

#BuildingtheBestSPS

WAY TO GO Nansemond Parkway Elementary School!

NPES is one of four winners from across the state to win the 2020 Reading Makes Cents Challenge.

Media Specialist Tosha Penkrot entered the contest, winning the school library a collection of financial literacy books valuing $500.

There is also a student Reading Makes Cents Challenge with 14 winners selected from across the state. Nansemond Parkway is excited to have two of their students win a Virginia529 college savings account with an initial balance of $529!

This is the third time the school has won this challenge and 4 students to date from the school have won a partially funded VIrginia529 college savings accounts.

Reading Makes Cents is a financial literacy reading program, available to K-5 students and librarians across the state of Virginia. The program teaches a multitude of financial literacy and SOL concepts through a selection of engaging books, lesson plans, and fun activities.
#BuildingtheBestSPS

Communication Helps Prevent Substance Abuse

You may think there's plenty of time before you need to talk to your child about drugs. This is not true. Young children are exposed to messages about drugs in the media.

Discuss the dangers with your child. Ask what your child has heard, and make your rules clear: No drugs ever (unless prescribed for your child). Parent-child communication is so important that some experts call it the "anti-drug."

Read this parent tip and more on our website! #BuildingtheBestSPS

Before A Test, Have Your Child Create One

There are many things your child can do to study for a test, but one of the best is to think like the teacher. After your child reviews his notes, have him make a list of questions he thinks might be on the test. Then he should prepare to answer them.

Chances are, some of his questions will show up on the test. Your child will feel confident if he's thought through the answers ahead of time.

Read this parent tip and more on our website! #BuildingtheBestSPS

The COPS Checklist Helps Kids Catch Writing Errors

Before your child hands in a writing assignment, help him use the COPS checklist to proofread it.

C is for capitalization. Does every sentence start with a capital letter? Are all the proper names capitalized?

O is for overall appearance. Is the paper neat and easy to read?

P is for punctuation. Are the sentences punctuated correctly?

S is for spelling. Has your child checked any word he's unsure of in a dictionary?

Read this parent tip and more on our website! #BuildingtheBestSPS

USE A SCHEDULE TO MAKE RESPONSIBILITY ROUTINE

To help your child finish homework and chores without having to nag him repeatedly, create a responsibility routine.

Write down a schedule with specific times for homework, chores, free time and screen time. If you stick to the schedule, your child will know he must finish homework, set the table and lay out his clothes for tomorrow before he plays. Have him check off each task as he completes it.

Read this parent tip and more on our website! #BuildingtheBestSPS

- Cover your cough and sneeze.
- If you have a fever, stay home from work/school until fever free for 24 hours, without the use of fever-reducing medications.

If we all work together, we can keep our schools healthy!

The Northern Shores elementary students, in Mr. Pulley's classes, conducted several scientific investigations in order to determine the differences between mixtures and solutions.

With the help of Mr. Pulley and Mrs. Valdivieso, the students conducted several experiments at different stations and discovered mixtures are heterogeneous and solutions are homogeneous.

You can still see the substances within a heterogeneous mixture and these substances can be separated.

Homogeneous mixtures or solutions cannot be separated, because most solutions are evenly mixed and one substance tends to dissolves (solute) into the other substance (solvent).
#BuildingtheBestSPS

Challenge Your Child To A Writing Game

Good writing unites individual ideas into an overall whole.

To help your child practice, give him or her a pack of index cards and have them write the name of a thing or an idea on each card. Then have her draw four cards and see if she can use all the ideas in a single sentence.

For example, if she had "toys," "trip," "sunny" and "teachers," she might write, "On sunny days, teachers let students take their toys on school trips."

Find this parent tip and more on our website at www.spsk12.net under the Parent tab. #tiptuesday #spsk12proud #BuildingtheBestSPS
